question: Some people say that the main environmental problem of our time is the loss of particular species of plants and animals. Others say that there are more important environmental problems. Discuss both these views and give your own opinion.
text: It is a common belief that the central environmental issue in the 21st century is the depletion of certain species of fauna and flora. Nevertheless, a more persuasive assertion is that water scarcity, which continually undermines the public’s health as we speak, should be the top priority. In this essay, I will attempt to look at both views and shed light on the preference for the latter.

On the one hand, the increasing number of dying plants and animals could induce a reduction in biodiversity and negatively affect the food chain. The study of wildlife has proven that the existences of these creatures and varieties are closely intertwined such that the loss of any link could consequently lead to the loss of another. However, one could critique that this phenomenon is merely a matter of natural selection. For instance, the death of certain species is inevitable to adapt to the ever-changing environment, and as a result, new species evolve.

On the other hand, the acute water shortage has far more detrimental repercussions for society. Occupying up to two-thirds of the human body and being used for countless purposes ranging from hydration, cooking, hygiene and irrigation, etc., water is indispensable not only to the survival of each individual but also to the well-being of the whole community. Moreover, a primary cause of the aforementioned elemental deficiency is contaminated sources that impose grave threats upon many people globally. This circumstance is especially prominent in impoverished areas with substandard and unsanitary living conditions. To illustrate, the high mortality rate of many Africans due to waterborne diseases is unequivocal proof of the gravity of clean water sufficiency.
In conclusion, while it would be imprudent to disregard the contraction of plants and animals, one cannot refute that the impacts of water scarcity are more palpable and deserve greater attention.
